"GODSPEED" .
The opening of the present collegiate year marks the termination
' the active service of Mr. Thomas R. Ball, who has resigned as
egistrar after having been associated with the University for fortyK years. In that period of time, Mr. Ball has seen class after class
'ter as freshmen; has seen them, some years later, leave the portals
the University to take their place in the world. He has known
Tee generations of Hopkins men and has taken personal interest
nearly all. His associates marvel at his faculty of recalling names
a id faces and there is hardly a graduate or undergraduate of Johns
opkins who does not retain some pleasant memory Of kindly interest and willing aid tendered him by the Registrar.
Johns Hopkins will miss "Tommy" Ball. He is the type of
an, so seldom seen, who .makes no enemies and has the world for
his friend. Our one desire is that, although Mr. Ball has seen fit to
retire from active service, he will continue his association with the
niversity as much and as long as possible.
The News-Letter has only to say "Godspeed." And it speaks
,t only for the undergraduates and alumni, not only for the Faculty,
it for every man who has eve!' had the good fortune to know
'ommy" Ball.

A. A. TICKETS TAKE NEW
FORM THIS YEAR
The Athletic Association cards
have been changed this year into
books with coupons intended for
each contest. This was done for
two very good reasons. It is unbelievable but, nevertheless, true,
that certain students would enter the gate with their A. A. cards
and then throw the card over the
fence to a waiting brother or a
friend, who would then use it to
obtain entrance. This practice,
which has been going on for some
time, will be stopped entirely by
the use of the new books. The
coupons collected at the gates will
be a means by which the student
body can be counted and their
support ascertained.

The opening of the present collegiate year marks the termination
' the active service of Mr. Thomas R. Ball, who has resigned as
egistrar after having been associated with the University for fortyK years. In that period of time, Mr. Ball has seen class after class
'ter as freshmen; has seen them, some years later, leave the portals
the University to take their place in the world. He has known
Tee generations of Hopkins men and has taken personal interest
nearly all. His associates marvel at his faculty of recalling names
a id faces and there is hardly a graduate or undergraduate of Johns
opkins who does not retain some pleasant memory Of kindly interest and willing aid tendered him by the Registrar.
Johns Hopkins will miss "Tommy" Ball. He is the type of
an, so seldom seen, who .makes no enemies and has the world for
his friend. Our one desire is that, although Mr. Ball has seen fit to
retire from active service, he will continue his association with the
niversity as much and as long as possible.
The News-Letter has only to say "Godspeed." And it speaks
,t only for the undergraduates and alumni, not only for the Faculty,
it for every man who has eve!' had the good fortune to know
'ommy" Ball.

A. A. TICKETS TAKE NEW
FORM THIS YEAR
The Athletic Association cards
have been changed this year into
books with coupons intended for
each contest. This was done for
two very good reasons. It is unbelievable but, nevertheless, true,
that certain students would enter the gate with their A. A. cards
and then throw the card over the
fence to a waiting brother or a
friend, who would then use it to
obtain entrance. This practice,
which has been going on for some
time, will be stopped entirely by
the use of the new books. The
coupons collected at the gates will
be a means by which the student
body can be counted and their
support ascertained.
